summary: Email chain from July 2021 between a federal prosecutor and FedEx legal staff regarding identifying a records custodian to authenticate FedEx records from 2008 for the upcoming Ghislaine Maxwell trial. The records relate to a 2008 subpoena from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida in the Jeffrey Epstein case.

persons.name: Tracy Chapell
persons.role: Senior Paralegal at Federal Express Corporation Legal Department
persons.context: FedEx employee corresponding with federal prosecutors about providing a records custodian to authenticate FedEx records from 2008 for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the upcoming trial in New York in November 2021, for which the FedEx records are being sought.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced by Tracy Chapell asking if the case is "the" Jeffrey Epstein case; the 2008 subpoena was from the Southern District of Florida Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Tracy Ferrara
persons.context: Identified as the FedEx point of contact for a 2008 subpoena from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

connections.description: Maxwell's trial is related to the Epstein case; the document seeks records from the earlier Epstein investigation for use in Maxwell's trial.
Chapell, as a FedEx legal staff member, is assisting prosecutors in obtaining records for Maxwell's trial.

events.title: Subpoena to FedEx from SD Florida
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida sent a subpoena to FedEx as part of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
events.description: Scheduled trial of Ghislaine Maxwell in New York, for which prosecutors are seeking to authenticate FedEx records from 2008.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Prosecutors in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial were seeking in July 2021 to authenticate FedEx records from a 2008 subpoena issued during the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.
The 2008 subpoena came from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, indicating federal interest in Epstein's activities at that time.
A FedEx paralegal explicitly asked if the request was related to "the" Jeffrey Epstein case, confirming the notoriety and ongoing legal relevance of the Epstein investigation.
The email chain shows continuity between the earlier Epstein investigation and the later Maxwell prosecution, with evidence from 2008 being prepared for use in the 2021 trial.
